Course Description: Algebraic structures are of fundamental importance in mathematics and play an increasingly significant role in many application areas, including computer science and communication. This course introduces the main algebraic structures: groups, rings and fields. Fundamental concepts and properties of these structures are studied, both in the abstract and in relation to concrete families of structures. Furthermore, algebra is an excellent vehicle for training students in mathematical rigour, proofs, and problem solving.

Course Outcomes.CO1: To explain algebraic properties of some important families of groups: permutation groups, dihedral groups, matrix groups.
Course Outcomes.CO2: To be able to classify groups up to isomorphism.
Course Outcomes.CO3: To discuss algebraic properties of rings and fields (particularly finite fields), and to be able to classify rings and fields up to isomorphism.
Course Outcomes.CO4: To be able to write down formal mathematical proofs.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Equivalence relation and partition. Groups and subgroups, Cyclic groups, Abelian groups, Matrix groups, Quaternionic group.
Lagrange's theorem, normal subgroup, quotient groups, isomorphism theorems, Group actions.
Permutation groups, Simple groups, Simplicity of the alternating group. Burnside's lemma and its applications.
Centralizers and Normalizers, the class equation and its applications. Dihedral Groups.
Direct product of groups, Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian groups
Rings and Fields, Matrix rings and Group rings, units and zero divisors, ideals, quotient rings, principal ideal, prime ideal, maximal ideal, nil and nilpotent ideals, integral domain.
Isomorphism of rings, Direct product of rings, Polynomial rings, The Chinese Remainder Theorem
Principal ideal domain, Euclidean domain, Unique factorization domain (basic algebraic properties only)

Textbook: 1. I N Herstein, Topics in Algebra, Wiley India Pvt Ltd, 2006.
2. J A Gallian, Contemporary Abstract Algebra, Narosa Book Distributors Private Ltd, 2004.
3. D. S. Dummit and R. M. Foote, Abstract Algebra, Wiley, 2003.
Reference book: 5. Niels Lauritzen, Concrete Abstract Algebra, Cambridge University Press.
6. Charles Pinter, A book of Abstract Algebra, Dover Publications Inc.
